stories.title: Jigsaw fixes bugs in machine-written software
XBackBone and ShareX – A Self Hosted Lightshot Alternative

stories.text:
Corporate networks have lots of resources around good practice: partitioning, zero trust, vlans etc. But home networks seem to me to be a giant attack surfaces, and incredibly juicy targets.

What constitutes modern best practice for the design and implementation of secure, performant home networks? Im thinking there must be more than NAT, tossing Alexa in the garbage and crossed fingers.
stories.title: Ask HN: Best practice for home network design

stories.text: I've gathered it's written in Arc lisp, and I've found various threads where people ask specific questions about it which are then answered by pg or dang, but I'm curious if there's been a comprehensive write-up somewhere. If nothing else, I'd be curious just to see what a non-toy lisp website looks like under the hood.
stories.title: Ask HN: Is there a technical writeup on the implementation of Hacker News?
